pr_title: Make JaxbAdapter tests compatible on Windows machines

timeline.message: Make JaxbAdapter tests compatible on Windows machines

timeline.bodyText:
Proposal B)
How about we use "\r?\n" instead of "\n"?
Proposal C) Why do we assert the formatting of the text? Is that needed?
Normally "\s*" includes all whitespace, including \r and \n.
Does this regex work for those 2 lines?
regex = "\\{\\s*\"([\\w]+)\"\\s:\\s\\{"
 + ...
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
If C) works, can we go with that? I don't think we need to test for formatting.
"\s*" (which is escaped written as "\s*"), means 0 or more whitespace characters.
replies.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: Or Proposal D): The official Java regex for newline since Java 8: "\R" (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html#lineending)
replies.author: Christopher-Chianelli
Christopher-Chianelli

replies.bodyText:
+1 to using \R for Java regex. What would we use for new line characters in the error messages?
-1 to using ObjectMapper, I don't think we should introduce Jackson dependencies since this code deals with the JAXB JSON standard. We do use ObjectMapper in the optaplanner-persistence-jackson module. If we do decide to use it, it's outside the scope of this PR.
replies.author: cuijulian

replies.bodyText:
String.format(...) is a thing, and use "%n" (https://dzone.com/articles/java-string-format-examples) (note it varargs are not type safe, it basically sprintf).
How about using JAXBContext to create a new unmarshaller to read the json?
replies.author: Christopher-Chianelli

replies.bodyText: %n looks reasonable. Let's see if we can get consensus on which newline char to use. As for the rest, a bit of scope creep here, the purpose of this PR was to fix the broken Windows tests. We can address how we assert the Json output in a separate PR.
replies.author: cuijulian

replies.bodyText:
The JSON format is whitespace (and therefore newline) agnostic. Whether one puts newlines and 4 space indents into a JSON file is a matter of taste (= code style).
We need to test if it's formatted as JSON.
Do we need to test if the JSON "code style" is adhered too? I am not sure. If we don't, then we can just put \\s*, this will match all and any whitespacing (including linefeed and newline characters). If we do want to test it, then this is fine.
Either way, +1 to merge.
replies.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: Hmm, good points. I don't see why we shouldn't test for JSON code style. If anything it's a more strict test, so I am in favour of keeping it. Are there any examples where testing for "style" rather than just "format" is not a good choice?
replies.author: cuijulian

timeline.bodyText: Using System.lineSeperator() makes me cringe. Can't remember/motivate why though... For some reason, it's taboo.
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
I haven't found anything wrong about it. Even OpenJDK seems to be switching to it:
https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8198645
replies.author: rsynek
